Generative function combinators¬∂

This module holds a set of generative function implementations called generative function combinators.

These combinators accept generative functions as arguments, and return generative functions with modified choice map shapes and behavior.

They are used to express common patterns of computation, including if-else (SwitchCombinator), mapping across vectorial arguments (MapCombinator), and dependent for-loop (UnfoldCombinator).

üî™ (A sharp bit) GenJAX combinator restrictions üî™

The implementations of these combinators are similar to those in Gen.jl, but JAX imposes extra restrictions on their construction and usage.

In contrast to Gen.jl, UnfoldCombinator must have the number of unfold steps specified ahead of time as a static constant. The length of the the unfold chain cannot depend on a variable whose value is known only at runtime.

Similarly, for MapCombinator ‚Äì the shape of the vectorial arguments which will be mapped over must be known at JAX tracing time.

These restrictions are not due to the implementation, but are fundamental to JAX‚Äôs programming model (as it stands currently).

Switch¬∂

This module implements a generative function combinator which allows branching control flow for combinations of generative functions which can return different shaped choice maps. It‚Äôs based on encoding a trace sum type using JAX - to bypass restrictions from jax.lax.cond.

Generative functions which are passed in as branches to SwitchCombinator must accept the same argument types, and return the same type of return value.

The internal choice maps for the branch generative functions can have different shape/dtype choices.

class genjax.combinators.switch.SwitchCombinator(*branches)[source]¬∂

SwitchCombinator accepts a set of generative functions as input configuration and implements a branching control flow pattern. This combinator provides a ‚Äúsum‚Äù Trace type which allows the internal generative functions to have different choice maps.

This pattern allows GenJAX to express existence uncertainty over random choices ‚Äì as different generative function branches need not share addresses.

Usage of the Generative function interface is detailed below under each method implementation.

Parameters:

*args (GenerativeFunction) ‚Äì A splatted sequence of GenerativeFunction instances should be provided to the SwitchCombinator constructor.

Returns:

A single SwitchCombinator generative function which implements a branch control flow pattern using each provided internal generative function (see parameters) as a potential branch.

Return type:

SwitchCombinator

Example

import jax
import genjax

@genjax.gen
def branch_1(key):
    key, x = genjax.trace("x1", genjax.Normal)(key, (0.0, 1.0))
    return (key, )

@genjax.gen
def branch_2(key):
    key, x = genjax.trace("x2", genjax.Bernoulli)(key, (0.3, ))
    return (key, )

switch = genjax.SwitchCombinator(branch_1, branch_2)

key = jax.random.PRNGKey(314159)
jitted = jax.jit(genjax.simulate(switch))
key, _ = jitted(key, (0, ))
key, tr = jitted(key, (1, ))
print(tr)

SwitchTrace(
  gen_fn=SwitchCombinator(
    branches={
      0:
      JAXGenerativeFunction(source=<function branch_1>),
      1:
      JAXGenerativeFunction(source=<function branch_2>)
    }
  ),
  chm=Mask(
    inner=Trie(
      nodes={
        'x1':
        DistributionTrace(
          gen_fn=_Normal(),
          args=(f32[], f32[]),
          value=f32[],
          score=f32[]
        ),
        'x2':
        DistributionTrace(
          gen_fn=_Bernoulli(),
          args=(f32[],),
          value=bool[],
          score=f32[]
        )
      }
    ),
    mask=Trie(
      nodes={
        'x1':
        DistributionTrace(
          gen_fn=_Normal(),
          args=(bool[], bool[]),
          value=bool[],
          score=bool[]
        ),
        'x2':
        DistributionTrace(
          gen_fn=_Bernoulli(),
          args=(bool[],),
          value=bool[],
          score=bool[]
        )
      }
    )
  ),
  args=(),
  retval=(),
  score=f32[]
)

Unfold¬∂

This module implements a generative function combinator which allows statically unrolled control flow for generative functions which can act as kernels (a kernel generative function can accept their previous output as input).

class genjax.combinators.unfold.UnfoldCombinator(kernel: GenerativeFunction, length: int)[source]¬∂

UnfoldCombinator accepts a single kernel generative function as input and a static unroll length which specifies how many iterations to run the chain for.

A kernel generative function is one which accepts and returns the same signature of arguments. Under the hood, UnfoldCombinator is implemented using jax.lax.scan - which has the same requirements.

Parameters:

  • gen_fn (GenerativeFunction) ‚Äì A single kernel GenerativeFunction instance.

  • length (Int) ‚Äì An integer specifying the unroll length of the chain of applications.

Returns:

A single UnfoldCombinator generative function which implements the generative function interface using a scan-like pattern. This generative function will perform a dependent-for iteration (passing the return value of generative function application) to the next iteration for length number of steps. The programmer must provide an initial value to start the chain of iterations off.

Return type:

UnfoldCombinator

Example

import jax
import genjax

@genjax.gen
def random_walk(key, prev):
    key, x = genjax.trace("x", genjax.Normal)(key, (prev, 1.0))
    return (key, x)


unfold = genjax.UnfoldCombinator(random_walk, 1000)
init = 0.5
key = jax.random.PRNGKey(314159)
key, tr = jax.jit(genjax.simulate(unfold))(key, (init,))
print(tr)

UnfoldTrace(
  gen_fn=UnfoldCombinator(
    kernel=JAXGenerativeFunction(source=<function random_walk>),
    length=1000
  ),
  length=i32[],
  subtrace=JAXTrace(
    gen_fn=<function random_walk>,
    args=(f32[1000],),
    retval=(f32[1000],),
    choices=Trie(
      nodes={
        'x':
        DistributionTrace(
          gen_fn=_Normal(),
          args=(f32[1000], f32[1000]),
          value=f32[1000],
          score=f32[1000]
        )
      }
    ),
    score=f32[1000]
  ),
  args=(f32[],),
  retval=(f32[],),
  score=f32[]
)

Map¬∂

This module implements a generative function combinator which allows broadcasting for generative functions ‚Äì mapping over vectorial versions of their arguments.

class genjax.combinators.map.MapCombinator(kernel: GenerativeFunction, in_axes: Tuple)[source]¬∂

MapCombinator accepts a single generative function as input and provides vmap-based implementations of the generative function interface methods. MapCombinator also accepts in_axes as an argument to specify exactly which axes of the (key, *args) should be broadcasted over.

Parameters:

  • gen_fn (GenerativeFunction) ‚Äì A single GenerativeFunction instance.

  • in_args (Tuple[Int]) ‚Äì A tuple specifying which (key, *args) to broadcast over.

Returns:

A single MapCombinator generative function which implements vmap support for each generative function interface method.

Return type:

MapCombinator

Example

import jax
import jax.numpy as jnp
import genjax

@genjax.gen
def add_normal_noise(key, x):
    key, noise1 = genjax.trace("noise1", genjax.Normal)(
            key, (0.0, 1.0)
    )
    key, noise2 = genjax.trace("noise2", genjax.Normal)(
            key, (0.0, 1.0)
    )
    return (key, x + noise1 + noise2)

mapped = genjax.MapCombinator(add_normal_noise, in_axes=(0, 0))

arr = jnp.ones(100)
key = jax.random.PRNGKey(314159)
key, *subkeys = jax.random.split(key, 101)
subkeys = jnp.array(subkeys)
_, tr = jax.jit(genjax.simulate(mapped))(subkeys, (arr, ))
print(tr)

MapTrace(
  gen_fn=MapCombinator(
    kernel=JAXGenerativeFunction(source=<function add_normal_noise>),
    in_axes=(0, 0)
  ),
  length=i32[],
  subtrace=JAXTrace(
    gen_fn=<function add_normal_noise>,
    args=(f32[100],),
    retval=(f32[100],),
    choices=Trie(
      nodes={
        'noise1':
        DistributionTrace(
          gen_fn=_Normal(),
          args=(f32[100], f32[100]),
          value=f32[100],
          score=f32[100]
        ),
        'noise2':
        DistributionTrace(
          gen_fn=_Normal(),
          args=(f32[100], f32[100]),
          value=f32[100],
          score=f32[100]
        )
      }
    ),
    score=f32[100]
  ),
  score=f32[]
)
